Congrats to ByteDance's Intelligent Creation (IC) team in Singapore. A research paper co-authored by a ByteDance researcher and the National University of Singapore has been accepted by Nature Neuroscience, one of the leading scientific journals in the field of neuroscience. The paper is titled "Meta-matching as a simple framework to translate phenotypic predictive models from big to small data." Brain imaging technology is a key field in neuroscience. It can be used for observing the neurochemical changes in the brain during information processing and stimulus-response, providing an important reference for the diagnosis and treatment of diseases.There is significant interest in using brain imaging data to predict non-brain-imaging phenotypes (the set of observable characteristics or traits of an organism) in individuals. However, most prediction studies rely on very limited data, making them less reliable. The team approached this issue with a unique framework of "meta-matching," or translating predictive models from large-scale datasets to new unseen non-brain-imaging phenotypes. "We demonstrated that meta-matching can boost the prediction of new phenotypes in small independent datasets by 100% to 400% in many scenarios."You can read more about the team's paper in Nature Neuroscience https://lnkd.in/dZJTp7xsAre you interested in joining one of our award-winning teams?
